I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) a proposed 
loan, and (ii) a proposed grant, both to the Kingdom of Cambodia for subprogram 2 of the 
Promoting Economic Diversification Program (PED-SP2); and (iii) a proposed grant for capacity 
development  for  the  Competition,  Regulatory  Efficiency,  and  Small  and  Medium-Sized 
Enterprise Technology (CREST) Project. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 
1.  
 
2.  PED-SP2 will support the government’s key reform priorities aimed at diversifying the 
sources of economic growth, supported by increased contribution of the private sector. The 
reform priorities include efforts to enhance governance in the business climate by promoting 
competition policy and regulatory efficiency. PED-SP2 also aims to increase private sector 
competitiveness  through  innovation  and  enhanced  trade  facilitation  measures.  The 
Development Policy Letter is in Appendix 3 and the Policy Matrix is in Appendix 4. 
 
II.  THE PROGRAM 
 
A.  Rationale 
 
3.  Reforms to the business climate implemented under the National Strategic Development 
Plan 2006–2010 (NSDP) and sector strategies have helped Cambodia move up 15 places in the 
World Bank Group’s Doing Business global rankings since 2006.1 Despite this progress, much 
needs to be done to attract investment and generate better jobs for a rapidly expanding labor 
force. As Cambodia’s economy advances, new policy and structural challenges for the private 
sector need to be addressed. These include emerging competition policy issues in key sectors, 
the high business compliance costs of regulations (estimated at 3%-5% of gross domestic 
product), low levels of innovative activity in the private sector, and the relatively high cost in 
trade facilitation. Food safety is poor in Cambodia and this is a barrier to private sector growth 
and international trade in processed food products, which has huge growth potential. It is also a 
major  risk  to  the  human  population  and  lowers  productivity.  With  over  60,000  enterprises 
engaged in the food sector, reforming sanitary and phytosanitary standards (SPS) management 
systems is a critical part of the government’s economic diversification strategy.2  
 
4.  The PED cluster approved by the Board of Directors of the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB)  in  December  2008  comprises  three  subprograms  from  2008  to  2012. 3  Under 
subprogram 1 (PED-SP1), financed by ADB ($19 million) in 2008, the government implemented 
a series of investment and trade facilitation measures that laid the foundations for a more 
competitive and diversified economy in the longer term. It also included the first SPS capacity 
development project (SPS-1 project) financed by ADB ($2 million). The current phase, PED-
SP2, builds on progress made under PED-SP1 for investment climate, trade policy, and trade 
facilitation. It also responds to new policy challenges arising from the impact of the global 
financial crisis such as the need for competition policy, regulatory efficiency, and innovation to 
promote private sector competitiveness. These reforms are designed to promote economic 
diversification by (i) enhancing competition in domestic markets and lower cost regulation, 
(ii) strengthening  investor  confidence  in  the  regulatory  environment  and  promoting  market-
based innovation, and (iii) strengthening trade facilitation measures along the entire supply

3  ADB. 2008. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Program Cluster,

chain. ADB technical assistance has been targeted to support the government accomplish the 
policy triggers under PED-SP2.4 The final phase, PED-SP3, is expected to be completed at the 
end of 2012. PED-SP3 includes 10 policy triggers building on progress made under PED-SP2. 
 
5.  PED-SP2  has  several  features  that  draw  on  best  international  practice  for  a 
comprehensive trade and investment program. These include (i) supply-side incentives through 
improving trade policy and taxation related to international norms, (ii) capacity development 
assistance  to  address  constraints  of  SPS  service  providers  to  small  and  medium-sized 
enterprises (SMEs), (iii) addressing SMEs’ demand-side issues through a pilot SPS technology 
matching grants component, (iv) addressing issues of sustainability of reforms by establishing a 
permanent government body to oversee regulatory reforms, and (v) assisting Cambodia’s global 
and regional integration efforts via support for Cambodia’s World Trade Organization’s trade 
policy review (TPR) and its participation in the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) 
regional trade agreements and ASEAN commitments to develop competition policy and law.  
 
B.  Impact and Outcome 
 
6.  The impact of the PED cluster is an expanded and diversified private sector. By the end 
of 2015, the PED cluster is expected to have increased the share of nontraditional sectors in 
GDP and increased the share of non-garment exports in total exports of goods. The outcome of 
the PED cluster will be an improved business environment where the private sector operates 
efficiently and effectively. This will be reflected in an increased number of registered enterprises 
and increased growth in private investment.   
 
C.  Outputs 
 
7.  PED-SP2 supports the government’s efforts in three core reform areas: (i) improving 
competition  policy  and  regulatory  efficiency,  (ii)  strengthening  the  investment  climate  and 
innovation, and (iii) enhancing trade policy and facilitation. All 20 policy measures required for 
PED-SP2 were carried out by the end of August 2010.5 
 
1.  Output 1: Competition Policy and Regulatory Efficiency 
 
8.  PED-SP2 supports the government’s agenda to improve the regulatory environment for 
businesses. The objective is to promote greater competition in domestic markets and lower 
regulatory compliance costs faced by businesses. Critical reform areas include institutionalizing 
good  practices  in  regulation  and  regulatory  impact  assessments  (RIAs).6 The  following 
measures toward achieving these objectives were completed before Board consideration of 
PED-SP2. 
 
9.  Institutionalizing  good  practice  in  regulation  making.  A  major  reform  is  the 
government’s program to institutionalize good regulatory practices in the national government. 
To this end the government carried out the following steps (i) upgraded the Economic, Social 
and Cultural Council (ECOSOCC) at the Office of the Council of Ministers (OCM) with higher 
level policy status, increased personnel, and a broader policy mandate, including RIAs;7 and (ii)

the government (OCM) produced and endorsed a strategy to institutionalize RIAs in the national 
government, including preparation for and establishment of the Office of Regulatory Impact 
Assessment (ORIA) at ECOSOCC, which will oversee the RIA reforms. The OCM legal decision 
to establish the ORIA has been issued. The ORIA will be a permanent government body, 
modeled on institutional approaches used in other countries such as the Australian Office of 
Best Practice Regulation and the United Kingdom’s Office of Better Regulatory Practice. The 
ORIA  will  comprise  18 professional  staff  qualified  in  economics,  accounting,  business 
administration, and public administration. Recent graduates will fill a proportion of the positions. 
With ADB technical assistance the government undertook activities to build RIA practice and 
raise awareness of its benefits in government: (i) the Ministry for Industry, Mines and Energy 
(MIME) implemented the first pilot RIA action plan starting with the Department of Industry; (ii) 
the Ministry of Environment (MOE) prepared and endorsed its RIA action plan and initiated an 
RIA reviewing the cost of business compliance with a sub-decree; and (iii) the government in 
collaboration  with  ADB  and  other  development  partners  undertook  several  RIA  awareness 
raising  activities  including  workshops,  a  senior  executive  retreat,  an  exposure  visit  to  the 
Australian federal and state government offices of best practice regulation, and a red tape 
survey of enterprises.8 
 
10.  Competition law. The Ministry of Commerce (MOC) established a working group on 
competition policy responsible for raising awareness of its benefits and drafting a competition 
law under PED-SP3. ADB technical assistance will support the MOC to draft the competition law 
based on best regional practices, including the establishment of an administratively autonomous 
competition council. This is in line with ASEAN member states’ commitments to introduce 
competition policy and law by 2015.  
 
2.  Output 2: Investment Climate 
 
11.  PED-SP2  supports  the  government’s  goals  of  improving  the  investment  climate  by 
enhancing the investment incentives, investor protection, and promoting innovation and access 
to technology. Measures accomplished before Board consideration of PED-SP2 include the 
following:  (i) the  government  (General  Department  of  Tax  at  the  Ministry  of  Economy  and 
Finance [MEF]) started to build capacity for preparing for discussions on double tax agreements 
with major trading partners—including preparing a draft double tax agreement (DTA) model as 
the basis for future DTA negotiations since the government is expected to begin discussions 
with a regional trading partner for a DTA in 2011; (ii) Cambodia strengthened investor protection 
through investment chapters of regional agreements, including the agreement establishing the 
ASEAN–Australia–New Zealand free trade area (February 2009), ASEAN–People’s Republic of 
China free trade area (August 2009), and ASEAN–Republic of Korea free trade area (June 
2009);  (iii)  the  government  recognizes  that  Cambodia’s  low  rankings  in  global  surveys  of 
technology adoption and innovation are a constraint to enhancing competitiveness—to address 
this, the MIME established a taskforce on national technology policy and produced a draft 
strategic policy framework for technology and innovation for the SMEs sector.   
 
3.  Output 3: Trade Policy and Facilitation 
 
12.  PED-SP2 supports the government’s goals of continuing trade policy reforms to lower 
the cost of doing business for the private sector, and implementing measures to improve trade 
facilitation (customs and SPS) for enhanced competitiveness. The following measures were 
accomplished before Board consideration of PED-SP2.  
 
                                                 
8 Development Coordination (Appendix 2).

4   
13.  Continuing trade policy reforms. The MOC produced a draft bill on trade remedies 
consistent with best international practice and an economy-wide perspective. It is expected to 
be submitted to the National Assembly in 2011. With ADB technical assistance, the government 
started preparations for its first TPR under the World Trade Organization (WTO) process. The 
TPR will provide a review of Cambodia’s trade and investment policies, and this will help the 
government prioritize policy reforms. Substantial progress has been made and the TPR is 
scheduled  to  be  completed  in  November  2011.  The  Department  of  Notification  and  Legal 
Compliance (WTO department) at the MOC strengthened its notification systems within the 
department as the WTO focal point, Camcontrol as the inquiry point for SPS, and the MIME for 
technical barriers to trade. The WTO department started submitting notifications to the WTO in 
2009. This enhances transparency in the trade policy regime related to technical barriers to 
trade. 
 
14.  Customs reforms. The government has made substantial progress in implementing 
customs reforms since 2008, critical to improving trade facilitation at the border. Under PED-
SP2,  two  priority  measures  were  taken  to  improve  customs  facilitation:  (i)  the  General 
Department of Customs and Excise implemented and operationalized an automated system for 
customs data (ASYCUDA) at three major ports; as part of the customs system expansion 
project, the General Department of Customs and Excise undertook a needs assessment for 
national rollout of ASYCUDA, expected to commence in 2011; and (ii) the General Department 
of  Customs  and  Excise  made  substantial  progress  in  implementing  customs  transaction 
valuation (CTV) in line with WTO commitments, including establishing the transaction valuation 
research unit responsible for overseeing CTV implementation, and a private sector forum to 
monitor CTV implementation and provide inputs to implementation of CTV.   
 
15.  Improvement of sanitary and phytosanitary standard management systems. The 
government undertook measures to strengthen the institutional and regulatory framework for 
effective SPS (food safety) management systems. First, it produced draft interministerial prakas  
(regulation) delineating the legal and enforcement responsibilities of various ministries (MOC, 
MIME, the Ministry of Health, and the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries). The 
prakas is  expected to be issued in the fourth quarter of 2010 and will lay the foundations for an 
effective  SPS  regulatory  and  enforcement  coordination  mechanism  to  address  agency 
duplication in the SPS field. Second, the MIME developed, endorsed, and started implementing 
an action plan to commercialize the Industrial Laboratory Center of Cambodia (ILCC) by 2013. 
The  plan  covers  corporate  governance,  strengthening  the  technical  capacity  of  staff,  and 
measures for International Organization for Standardization (ISO) accreditation for major food 
safety tests.9 Third, satisfactory progress has been made in developing the Institute Standards 
Cambodia Conformity and Assessment Board for management and process standards. It is 
intended to have the ISC accredited as a Conformity and Assessment Board in early 2011. This 
will allow it to certify internationally recognized standards. 
 
D.  Program Costs and Financing 
 
16.  To support its reform initiatives, the government has requested a loan of SDR6,565,000 
($10 million equivalent) and an Asian Development Fund grant of $9 million to help finance 
PED-SP2. The $10 million loan equivalent will have 24-year term, including a grace period of 
8 years, an interest rate of 1.0% per annum during the grace period and 1.5% per annum 
thereafter, and such other terms and conditions set forth in the draft financing agreement. The 
                                                 
9  With assistance from ADB and the United Nations Industrial Development Organization, the ILCC will be ISO17025 
accredited with the National Association of Testing Authorities Australia for six microbiology tests expected in the 
fourth quarter of 2010. This means the ILCC’s certified tests will be internationally accepted. The ILLC will be the 
first Cambodian laboratory to be ISO17025 accredited.

5 
 
government will meet the remaining resource requirement. The proceeds of the program loan 
will be disbursed in accordance with the provisions of ADB’s Simplification of Disbursement 
Procedures and Related Requirements for Program Loans.10 PED-SP2 will provide for the 
retroactive financing for eligible expenditures incurred up to 180 days prior to loan and grant 
effectiveness. ADB will retain the right to audit the use of the loan and grant proceeds and to 
verify the accuracy of the withdrawal application certification. 
 
17.  The size of the PED-SP2 loan is based on consideration of a number of factors required 
to support implementation of program reforms. The key considerations include: (i) the relative 
importance of the sector to the economy, the weight and benefits of the reform program, and the 
leverage necessary to counter resistance from interest groups; (ii) the policy adjustment costs 
incurred by the government and stakeholders in implementing and complying with reforms; and 
(iii) the need to conform to the overall financing requirement from the country partnership 
strategy period.11 ADB staff estimates that the long-run benefits of the reform program are 
approximately 2.9% of GDP or over $300.5 million (in 2009 prices). These economic benefits 
include increased output and investment from a reduction in business costs of compliance with 
licensing, lower trade facilitation costs, and increased productivity due to lower incidence of food 
and water related diseases and premature mortality in the human population. The reforms have 
important distributive effects. It will increase employment and wages, with positively impacting 
female employment, simulated to rise by 4.7% from these reforms. The policy adjustment costs 
to the government and private sector are conservatively estimated as a discounted present 
value lump sum of $31.5 million (or $19.5 million without the present value lump sum).12 These 
adjustment costs include the administrative, enforcement and fiscal costs to the government in 
implementing and enforcing the reforms (estimated at $26.0 million or alternatively $14 million 
without present value lump sum estimates)—such as the investment cost to set up the ORIA at 
OCM including new staff and operating costs, investment costs to set up RIA units at line 
ministries, the rollout of the ASYCUDA to three customs posts during PED-SP2, the investment 
costs in implementing the action plan to commercialize the ILCC, restructuring costs at the ISC 
to be accredited as a conformity and assessment body, and costs involved in drafting legislation 
and the TPR process. The policy adjustment costs also include the increased business costs of 
compliance with the SPS reforms related to mandatory SPS-sensitive standards (conservatively 
estimated at $5.5 million).13 
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
18.  The MOC will be the executing agency for the PED-SP2. It will be responsible for the 
overall  implementation  of  PED-SP2,  including  carrying  out  all  policy  actions,  program 
administration, and maintenance of program records. The implementation arrangements under 
PED-SP1 will continue under PED-SP2. The MOC will use the Private Sector Development 
Sub-Steering Committee, chaired by the minister of commerce and comprising senior officials 
from  the  MEF  and  MIME.  The  steering  committee  is  responsible  for  coordinating  the 
implementation and sustaining policy actions, with MOC and relevant line agencies involved in 
supporting  the  program  (MIME,  MOE,  and  ECOSOCC).  The  steering  committee  will  meet 
quarterly to monitor progress and oversee implementation of the program. The MOC will be 
responsible for day-to-day program implementation activities, and will report on implementation 
progress. The MOC will also establish a program implementation unit (PIU), and assign a PIU

F.  Capacity Development Project Investment and Financing Plan 
 
19.  To support PED-SP2 implementation, the government requested ADB to provide a grant 
for capacity development in the CREST project. The CREST project will be funded under a 
grant of $5.0 million from ADB’s Special Funds resources. The project duration will be 2011–
2014 (about 3 years). The CREST project will comprise two subprojects. The first subproject will 
be the RIA subproject, which will focus on capacity development to institutionalize RIA in 
government, including establishing the ORIA, supporting line ministries to implement RIA action 
plans, and developing a community of practitioners in RIA and regulatory reform. The project 
administration manual (PAM) for the RIA subproject contains details of the implementation 
arrangements, accounting and reporting, and other operational issues.14  
 
20.  The second subproject is the SPS-2 subproject (the second phase of the SPS-1 project 
under PED-SP1), which will focus on enhancing the effectiveness of supply side provisioning of 
SPS services to the private sector and the demand side for SPS services and technologies. A 
special feature of the SPS-2 subproject is a matching grants component to assist SMEs access 
technology and upgrade product and process quality. The PAM for the SPS-2 contains details of 
the implementation arrangements, accounting and reporting, and other operational issues.15   
 
21.  The project is estimated to cost $5,430,000, of which $5,000,000 will be grant financed 
under  ADB’s  Special  Funds  resources.  The  government  counterpart  in-kind  funding  is 
$430,000. The investment plan is summarized in Table 1.

G.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
22.  ECOSOCC  in  the  Council  of  Ministers  will  be  the  executing  agency  for  the  RIA 
subproject.  Participating  line  ministries  (MIME,  MOC,  MOE,  and  at  least  one  other  line 
ministry/agency)  will  be  the  implementing  agencies.16 The  ORIA  within  ECOSOCC  will  be 
mandated to implement RIA throughout all government operations. It will be responsible for 
(i) coordinating  subproject  implementation  with  the  implementing  agencies,  (ii)  carrying  out 
administrative and fiduciary support, and (iii) supporting both government and ADB reporting 
requirements on the progress of the subproject. A PIU will be established within the executing 
agency. Given the large volume of activities (workshops, seminars, etc.), the advance payment 
facility will be used for procurement of goods and services. 
 
23.  The MIME will be the executing agency for the SPS-2 subproject. The MOC and the 
Ministry of Health will be the implementing agencies. The MIME will use the private sector 
development sub-steering committee on manufacturing and SMEs which will be responsible for 
coordinating the implementation and sustaining the subproject.  A PIU will be established within 
the executing agency. Given the large volume of activities (workshops, seminars, matching 
grants, etc.), the advance payment facility will be used for procurement of goods and services. 
 
24.  At  the  request  and  on  behalf  of  the  government,  ADB  will  select  and  engage  the 
consultants and administer the consultancy contracts of the two subprojects in accordance with 
its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time) and other 
arrangements satisfactory to ADB. This arrangement continues the one established for the 
SPS-1 project. The justification for ADB administration of the two subprojects is to overcome the 
governance problem of agency duplication in the SPS sector, and to ensure that both SPS and 
RIA priorities and reforms are synchronized across a wide range of agencies (footnotes 13 and 
14).  
 
25.  The implementation arrangements are summarized in Table 3 and described in detail in 
the two subproject PAMs. Two firms will be engaged to implement the activities under the two 
subprojects in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as 
amended from time to time), in addition to the standard procedures for the executing agency-

III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
 
A.  Governance 
 
26.  The  country’s  financial  management  systems  have  been  assessed  to  improve  the 
understanding  of  fiduciary  risks  and  determine  fiduciary  arrangements  for  PED-SP2.  This 
assessment was based on the sector work of ADB’s public financial management for rural 
development  program  cluster,  as  well  as  the  Integrated  Fiduciary  Assessment  and  Public 
Expenditure Review for 2003 and the Country Procurement Assessment for 2004, both led by 
World Bank.17 These assessments identified core areas to address with development partners’ 
support. The Integrated Fiduciary Assessment and Public Expenditure Review determined that 
the fiduciary risk in the use and management of public funds was high. As a consequence, the 
government developed and began implementing a medium-term public financial management 
reform  program  from  2004  to  2015,  supported  by  development  partners.  This  program

Loan for Subprogram 1, and Grant to the Kingdom of Cambodia for Public Financial Management for Rural 
Development Program. Manila.

9 
 
increases the amount of public resources allocated to planning and management to overcome 
the  significant  weaknesses  in  the  basic  systems  and  processes  for  budget  preparation, 
execution and control, reporting, and oversight. ADB, the World Bank, and other development 
partners are working closely with the government to implement improved public sector financial 
management  systems.  A  good  governance  framework  for  the  CREST  project  has  been 
developed and agreed with the executing agencies (footnotes 13 and 14).  
 
27.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with government. The specific policy requirements and supplementary measures are described 
in the PAMs.  
 
B.  Poverty and Social  
 
28.  Reforms under the PED-SP2 could reduce poverty by 2.0 percentage points.18  PED-
SP2 will contribute to a sustainable reduction in poverty through three channels. The first 
channel is through higher, broad-based and sustainable economic growth. By reducing the 
business compliance costs with the business licensing system, lowering trade facilitation costs, 
improving taxation and investor guarantees in line with international norms, private and foreign 
investment will increase across a broad range of sectors thereby supporting higher economic 
growth. The improvement is SPS management systems will aid government’s efforts to develop 
backward linkages with the agriculture sector. The second channel is through the labor market 
with increased real wages and hiring activity across most sectors from increased investment. 
The lower risk of food and water borne diseases in the human population will raise productivity 
and  improve  household  incomes.  The  third channel  is through  lower  prices  of  goods  and 
services. By improving transparency in trade policy, increased integration within the region and 
the rest of the world through trade policy and regulatory reforms, and implementing competition 
policy, domestic prices will fall through greater competition in the economy. PED-SP2 will have 
a positive impact on achieving the goal of gender equality through gender mainstreaming in the 
regulatory review process and equitable access of female entrepreneurs to the matching grants 
output under the SPS-2 subproject.19 
 
C.  Safeguards 
 
29.  PED-SP2  does  not  trigger  the  safeguard  policies  and  is  categorized  C  for  the 
environment, involuntary resettlement, and indigenous peoples. The following are agreed upon, 
and will be incorporated into the legal agreement. Consistent with its commitment to good 
governance, accountability, and transparency, ADB reserves the right to investigate, directly or 
through its agents, any alleged corrupt, fraudulent, collusive, or coercive practices relating to the 
program. The government agreed to cooperate, and shall cause any and all government offices, 
organizations, and entities involved in implementing the program to cooperate fully with any 
such investigation and to extend all necessary assistance, including providing access to all 
relevant books and records, as may be necessary, for the satisfactory completion of any such 
investigation. 
 
D.  Risks and Mitigating Measures

environment continues to improve to support domestic macroeconomic stability and growth, and 
(ii) the government will stay on course with key business regulatory reform measures. However, 
there are three main risks to PED-SP2 (Table 4).
